rest.sentence: Silicon  solar cell efficiently convert solar energy into electricity under the sun illumination, but its inherent intermittent power generation due to diurnal and seasonal cycle has usually allowed for the requirement for alternative power sources
Owing to the abundance, diversity and availability, rain drop energy is one of the most promising green energy sources
Hence, hybrid energy harvesting could be a promising strategy of achieving preferential hybrid performances without sacrificing the advantages in individual devices

Herein, we proposed a hybrid solar and rain energy harvesting device featuring the integration of triboelectric nanogenerator  top-cell and a crystalline Si solar cell bottom-cell by laminating perovskite quantum dots-embedded polydimethylsiloxane composite film  onto the Si solar cell, which endows enhanced electrical output performances under rainy days

To overcome the limitation of low external quantum efficiency  in the ultraviolet region of the Si solar cell, the PCE of the hybrid solar cell is significantly enhanced from 18.47% of bare Si solar cell to 20.16% owing to the anti-reflection effect of PQDP film and the down-conversion property of CsPbBr3 QDs doped with Ce3+ ions
Meanwhile, this hybrid solar cell presents excellent durability after continuous measurement over 7 days

This tandem hybrid solar cell provides a promising strategy to simultaneously scavenging the solar and rain energy and boosting the power conversion efficiency by introducing the perovskite QDs without affecting the efficiency of bare Si solar cell.
Download : Download high-res image Download : Download full-size image
With the massive growth of population and the advancement of science and technology, traditional fossil energies can no longer meet the energy needs of today's society
If effective measures are not taken in time, it will eventually bring indelible damage to earth

As the largest developing country today, China closely follows the pace of the world and proposes to achieve the goal of “carbon neutrality” by 2060 , which calls for new techniques to facilitate the transition from carbon-intensive fossil fuel-based energy to green, low-carbon and renewable energy

Solar energy is the cleanest and most abundant renewable energy source available on the earth, which can be harnessed by solar cells based on photovoltaic effect with relatively high conversion efficiency ,
However, its inherent intermittent power generation of traditional silicon  solar cell due to diurnal and seasonal cycle has usually called for the requirement for alternative generation sources
Water energy in the form of raindrops is another green energy sources owing to its abundance, diversity and availability, particularly the large amount remains underutilized

Triboelectric nanogenerator , since its discovery in 2012, has been widely developed to harvest untapped raindrop energy based on the coupling between triboelectric and electrostatic induction effects , which enables the hybrid energy harvesting is expected to break through the limitation that Si solar cell cannot almost generate electricity under rainy days.
In spite of extensive efforts have been made in recent years , the attainment of efficient electricity generation and power conversion efficiency for individual hybrid device is still difficult
Generally, the fabrication of such hybrid devices require consideration of three critical factors

Firstly, the TENG that harvests raindrop energy must possess high transparency and maintain the power conversion efficiency without sacrificing the light absorption of solar cell; Secondly, the triboelectrification layer of TENG requires dielectrics with high electronegativity to generate abundant surface charges once the raindrops slip off; Thirdly, endowing the triboelectrification layer with anti-reflection function could undoubtedly enhance the power generation efficiency of Si solar cell, which in turn improves the hybrid energy conversion efficiency
Guided by the abovementioned criteria, great endeavors have been made towards easy droplet detachment by tailoring surface wettability

For example, the hybrid tandem TENG/Si solar cell decorated with patterned microbowl-array structure  and nanowrinkled polydimethylsiloxane   surfaces as well as Moth’s eye mimicking quartz glass , which all demonstrates excellent droplet repellency and improved water energy harvesting performances
However, the patterned surfaces that simply superimposed on the Si solar cell would significantly affect the transmittance and resulted in a reduced power conversion efficiency of solar cell

On the other hand, most of the reported works adopting single-electrode mode for scavenging the raindrop energy, leading to a relatively low energy conversion efficiency of TENG and difficulty in energy compensation for the Si solar cell under rainy days.

In this work, a tandem TENG/Si hybrid solar cell is developed by overlaying a top perovskite quantum dots-embedded polydimethylsiloxane  film based TENG on the bottom monocrystalline Si solar cell towards scavenging raindrop energy and solar energy simultaneously

The transparent PQDP composite film is introduced as a dual-functional layer, working as the triboelectrification charge density enhancement layer for raindrop energy harvesting as well as a down-conversion functional layer by converting the ultraviolet light that cannot be absorbed by Si cells
Moreover, the luminescence intensity of QDs and the down-conversion performance can be significantly increased through further doping perovskite QDs with Ce3+ ions
At an optimal perovskite QDs loading, the champion device delivered a peak open-circuit voltage and a short-circuit current of 80.5 V and 21.5μA per raindrop, respectively

In addition, the power conversion efficiency of crystalline Si solar cell has also been improved reaching 20.16% under air mass global  simulated sunlight irradiation in comparison to 18.47% for the bared cell

This work can not only improve the conversion efficiency of Si solar cells, but also adopt rainwater energy harvesting compensation measures to make up for the defect of low power generation efficiency of cells in rainy days

This work provides a promising strategy to simultaneously scavenging the solar and rain energy and boosting the power conversion efficiency by overcoming the limitation of low external quantum efficiency in the UV region of the Si solar cell through introducing the perovskite QDs based dual-functional layer.
To fabricate the PQDP composite film, the perovskite QDs are synthesized firstly through a thermal injection methodology according to previously reported approach  as demonstrated on Fig
1a, high-performance perovskite QDs are extracted by layer-by-layer purification and washing process
The transmission electron microscope  images of CsPbBr3 QDs are demonstrated in Fig
1b, which indicates that the cubic QDs nanoparticles were successfully

In summary, a PQDP-TENG/Si tandem hybrid solar cell is developed by integrating the crystalline Si solar cell and PQDP based TENG, successfully realizing the hybrid energy harvesting of rain and solar energy as well as boosting the power conversion efficiency

By embedding the CsPbBr3 QDs into the PDMS film, the overall dripping performance including VOC, ISC and peak power density of the PQDP based TENG can reach 80.5 V, 20.3 μA and 1.27 W m−2, respectively, which improves 23.8% compared to
Cesium carbonate , lead iodide  and cerium bromide  were obtained from Aladdin
Oleic acid , oleylamine , lead bromide  n-hexane  and methylacetate  were purchased from Macklin
Polydimethylsiloxane  and octadecene  were purchased from Dow Corning and J&K Scientific, respectively

Jingbo Yuan received his B.S
degree in New Energy Science and Engineering from Jiangsu Ocean University in 2020
He is currently pursuing his master degree in Jinan University
His research interests are mainly focused on structure design and hybrid energy harvesting based on triboelectric nanogenerator and solar cell.

Wearable electronics with conductive yet stretchable bio-interfaces, multimodal health regulating capabilities, and strong weather resistance are especially expected by athletes and outdoor workers, yet conventional rigid, impermeable, and monofunctional wearables can hardly meet these requirements simultaneously

Here, a hierarchical and ultrastretchable all-in-one health-regulating electronic textile  with robust superhydrophobic and antibacterial surfaces is developed through electrospin-assisted layer-by-layer assembly and liquid metal  printing

Skin-like and bio-compatible styrene-ethylene-butylene-styrene  nonwoven textile is employed as a breathable matrix for the layered E-textile, in which an electrophysiological recording circuit, a strain-sensing circuit, and a Joule heating circuit are successively patterned using EGaIn

To ensure human skin health and weather resistance of the device, antibacterial and waterproof surfaces are respectively installed on both sides of the electronic textile via anchoring functionalized nanoparticles

Thus, this ultrastretchable  AIO E-textile shows favorable moisture permeability , exceptional water repellency, remarkable antibacterial efficacy  against E-coli, and low-watt Joule heating ability, which even exhibits accurate under-water motion detection capability, and high-definition acquiring of bioelectrical signals  and surface electromyography ) when used as flexible epidermal bioelectrode
This work opens up a new avenue for daily applicable and multifunctional on-skin electronics.

Recent advances in the use of organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites have been investigated in a variety of applications, such as solar cells, photodetectors, light-emitting devices, and lasers, because of their outstanding semiconductor properties
Furthermore, the perovskite structure can host extrinsic elements, making it a promising candidate for battery applications
Previous studies have shown that organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites can be suitable anode materials for both lithium- and sodium-ion batteries
However, multivalent rechargeable batteries with perovskite materials have not yet been realized
Herein, we studied the electrochemical performance of three-dimensional  and long-chain alkylammonium 23Pb4I13 23Pb4I13) thin films as electrode materials for rechargeable Al-ion batteries

Our results showed that 23Pb4I13 presented a specific capacity of 257 mAh g–1 at a current density of 0.1 A g−1 and delivered 108 mAh g–1 after 250 cycles at a current density of 0.3 A g−1 with a retention of as high as 91 %, demonstrating a crucial role of isobutyl amine  due to the unique hydrogen-bonding interaction of isobutyl amine that hinders the shuttle effect of polyiodide
The results open a new direction for the use of organic–inorganic hybrid perovskites for new secondary aluminum ion batteries.
In the face of sustainable energy development, electricity generation using liquid infiltration in small-sized channels has become one of the effective strategies to optimize energy utilization
As p-type semiconductors, CuO nanomaterials exhibit great potential in energy storage and conversion, which can be used as suitable active materials for constructing nanogenerators
In this study, we proposed CuO water infiltration–induced electrical devices based on starfish-like particles and nanowires  interwoven architecture
Attributed to the ionovoltaic effect, the electrical signal value is reflected by the difference in carrier concentration between wet and dry regions
Notably, we innovatively used the oxidation–reduction–reoxidation method to control the crystal structure of CuO
In addition, we examined the relationship between CuO microstructure and performance and further explored the effect of different reaction conditions on the device output performance

It was demonstrated that a single device  can generate an open-circuit voltage  of 0.67 V and a short-circuit current  of 2.49 μA at room temperature when 30 μL of 0.1 mol L−1 NaCl solution permeates from one end of the film

Under a 0.5 mol L−1 NaCl condition , the device can generate a Voc of 0.82 V and an Isc of 2.70 μA, which is expected to be utilized in the field of sensors for identifying the different concentrations of ions.
Flexible tactile sensors are under high pursuit for wearable healthcare devices
However, challenges still exist in achieving both wearing comfortability through air permeability and hydrophobicity to resist water splash or even to be used in the special underwater circumstance

Inspired by the smart bio-structure of lotus leaf, we develop a flexible, breathable, waterproof and self-cleaning tactile sensor by sandwiching one ionogel electrolyte between two polydopamine /MXene/stearic acid  fabric electrodes

The micro-channels in the fabric and the through-holes in the gel endow the sensor with a high air breathability of 723.5 mm s−1 and the STA micro-sheets decorated on the outside surface of the sensor provide hydrophobicity with a large water droplet contact angle of 140.7° for the unique properties of self-cleaning and washability

By taking advantage of the supercapacitive sensing mechanism, the microstructures of MXene nanosheets on microfibers and the using of an interlayer with an internal aperture to initially separate electrodes and electrolyte, an extremely high sensitivity of up to 1677.79 kPa−1 is achieved

Practical sensing applications of the developed flexible sensors worn on different parts of human body for physiological signal monitoring, motion detection and silent information communication through Morse code in the special underwater circumstance are demonstrated.
Conventional methods of protecting against airborne pathogens, such as face masks, are typically associated with significant pressure loss and uncomfortable long-term wear

Alternative methods, such as antimicrobial textiles, can utilize nanomaterial-modified functional fabrics for effective microbial prevention, but suffer from limited treatment throughput, high cost, and potential toxicity from nanomaterial release

Herein, we develop a novel microbial-blocking textile using fabrics with opposite triboelectric properties of the outer and inner layers, which induces triboelectric charges by harvesting kinetic energy from human motion
The induced triboelectric negative charges at the outer textile layer achieve efficient airborne pathogen blocking based on electrostatic repulsion between the fabric and microbes
This self-powered, triboelectrification-induced microbial blocking system with optimized material  and structure  achieves highly efficient microbial blocking  at a very high airflow rate of 2.0 m/s
In addition, the pressure drop for microbial blocking by this novel method is extremely low
Our results demonstrate a promising method for rapid, self-powered blocking of airborne pathogens by incorporating triboelectric charges from human motion to meet vital public health needs.
The occurrence of extreme events  is unprecedented in the observed record and will increase with increasing global warming, leading to severe human health issues
Wearing suitable garments in different weather is one of the solutions for people to ease their physical discomfort in an energy-saving way
However, only one piece of traditional clothes hardly satisfies the demand of the changing weather

Herein, a multi-weather full-body triboelectric garment with a one-way moisture transport structure is presented to keep people feeling cool in the scorching weather while capturing droplet energy in rainy situations

A trilayer progressive wetting structure was designed to effectively transport sweat from the inner layer near the skin to the outer layer to keep the skin dry and comfortable in the muggy air, with a unidirectional transmission index of 1025%
When it starts to rain, the rain droplets quickly roll down the textile surface and generate triboelectric energy with the hydrophobic surface and conductive MXene layer inside
More than that, the scalable fabrication process makes it possible to obtain the textile with enough areas for making a whole garment, which is much more practical in real application scenarios.

degree in New Energy Science and Engineering from Jiangsu Ocean University in 2020
He is currently pursuing his master degree in Jinan University
His research interests are mainly focused on structure design and hybrid energy harvesting based on triboelectric nanogenerator and solar cell.

in the School of Energy and Environment from City University of Hong Kong in 2017
Her current research is mainly focused on the areas of hybrid energy harvesting, self-powered sensing and power management based on triboelectric nanogenerators.

degree in Communication Engineering from the School of Information Science and Technology of Wenhua University in 2019
He is currently studying for a master's degree at Jinan University in Guangzhou, China
His research interests include structure design and energy management circuit design based on triboelectric nanogenerators and solar cells.

degree in Applied Physics from Shandong University of Science and Technology  in 2018
He is currently pursuing his PhD degree at Yunnan Normal University
His research interests mainly focus on hybrid energy harvesting using triboelectric nanogenerators.

degree in South China Agricultural University in 2021

His research interests are mainly focused on hybrid energy harvesting.

He is currently pursuing his master degree in Jinan University
His research interests mainly focus on hybrid energy harvesting using triboelectric nanogenerators.
Yudi Wang is an Associate Professor in the School of Chemical Engineering at Dalian University of Technology Dr
She received her M.S
degree in Chemical Engineering and Technology from Dalian University of Technology in 2013 and received her Ph.D
degree in Inorganic Chemistry from Jilin University in 2018
Her research interests mainly focus on new optoelectronic materials and devices, and their applications in highly efficient photovoltaic modules and multi-energy integrated acquisition.
LProf
Vaillant-Roca completed her PhD in Physics Faculty at University of Havana  in 2008
She is currently an Auxiliary Researcher in the Institute of Materials Science and Technology at University of Havana since 2015

Her current research interests include growth and characterizations of semiconductor thin films, physical mechanism involved in the performance of solar cells and nanostructured materials for the third-generation solar cells.

Jialong Duan is currently a full Professor in the Institute of Carbon Neutrality, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering at Shandong University of Science and Technology from 2022 after receiving his Ph.DProf
from Ocean University of China
His research interests cover all-inorganic perovskite solar cells, dye-sensitized solar cells and multi-energy integrated photovoltaics.
Qunwei Tang is a senior Professor in the College of Chemical and Biological Engineering at Shandong University of Science and TechnologyProf
He is the dean of Institute of Carbon Neutrality and youth editor for eScience journal
His research interests cover perovskite solar cells and triboelectric nanogenerators
Up to date, he has published more than 350 papers in international journals such as Angewandte Chemie International Edition, Advanced Materials and two professional books
He has been listed in Chinese Most Cited Researchers, Career Scientific Impact , World's Top 2% Scientists

He also won the Second Prize of Scientific Research Outstanding Achievement Award  of Institutions of Higher Learning , the second prize of Guangdong Province Science and Technology Award , the first prize of Yunnan Province Science and Technology .
